trans-unit.source: Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Conceptual reference and overview of the offline data sync feature for Azure Mobile Apps
trans-unit.target: Conceptual reference and overview of the offline data sync feature for Azure Mobile Apps

trans-unit.source: Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps
trans-unit.target: Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps

trans-unit.source: What is offline data sync?
trans-unit.target: What is offline data sync?

trans-unit.source: Offline data sync is a client and server SDK feature of Azure Mobile Apps that makes it easy for developers to create apps that are functional without a network connection.
trans-unit.target: Offline data sync is a client and server SDK feature of Azure Mobile Apps that makes it easy for developers to create apps that are functional without a network connection.

trans-unit.source: When your app is in offline mode, users can still create and modify data, which will be saved to a local store.
trans-unit.target: When your app is in offline mode, users can still create and modify data, which will be saved to a local store.

trans-unit.source: When the app is back online, it can synchronize local changes with your Azure Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: When the app is back online, it can synchronize local changes with your Azure Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: The feature also includes support for detecting conflicts when the same record is changed on both the client and the backend.
trans-unit.target: The feature also includes support for detecting conflicts when the same record is changed on both the client and the backend.

trans-unit.source: Conflicts can then be handled either on the server or the client.
trans-unit.target: Conflicts can then be handled either on the server or the client.

trans-unit.source: Offline sync has a number of benefits:
trans-unit.target: Offline sync has a number of benefits:

trans-unit.source: Improve app responsiveness by caching server data locally on the device
trans-unit.target: Improve app responsiveness by caching server data locally on the device

trans-unit.source: Create robust apps that remain useful when there are network issues
trans-unit.target: Create robust apps that remain useful when there are network issues

trans-unit.source: Allow end-users to create and modify data even when there is no network access, supporting scenarios with little or no connectivity
trans-unit.target: Allow end-users to create and modify data even when there is no network access, supporting scenarios with little or no connectivity

trans-unit.source: Sync data across multiple devices and detect conflicts when the same record is modified by two devices
trans-unit.target: Sync data across multiple devices and detect conflicts when the same record is modified by two devices

trans-unit.source: Limit network use on high-latency or metered networks
trans-unit.target: Limit network use on high-latency or metered networks

trans-unit.source: The following tutorials show how to add offline sync to your mobile clients using Azure Mobile Apps:
trans-unit.target: The following tutorials show how to add offline sync to your mobile clients using Azure Mobile Apps:

trans-unit.source: [iOS: Enable offline sync]
trans-unit.target: [iOS: Enable offline sync]

trans-unit.source: [Xamarin iOS: Enable offline sync]
trans-unit.target: [Xamarin iOS: Enable offline sync]

trans-unit.source: [Xamarin Android: Enable offline sync]
trans-unit.target: [Xamarin Android: Enable offline sync]

trans-unit.source: [Windows 8.1: Enable offline sync]
trans-unit.target: [Windows 8.1: Enable offline sync]

trans-unit.source: What is a sync table?
trans-unit.target: What is a sync table?

trans-unit.source: To access the "/tables" endpoint, the Azure Mobile client SDKs provide interfaces such as `IMobileServiceTable` (.NET client SDK) or `MSTable` (iOS client).
trans-unit.target: To access the "/tables" endpoint, the Azure Mobile client SDKs provide interfaces such as `IMobileServiceTable` (.NET client SDK) or `MSTable` (iOS client).

trans-unit.source: These APIs connect directly to the Azure Mobile App backend and will fail if the client device does not have a network connection.
trans-unit.target: These APIs connect directly to the Azure Mobile App backend and will fail if the client device does not have a network connection.

trans-unit.source: To support offline use, your app should instead use the *sync table* APIs, such as `IMobileServiceSyncTable` (.NET client SDK) or `MSSyncTable` (iOS client).
trans-unit.target: To support offline use, your app should instead use the *sync table* APIs, such as `IMobileServiceSyncTable` (.NET client SDK) or `MSSyncTable` (iOS client).

trans-unit.source: All the same CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) work against sync table APIs, except now they will read from or write to a *local store*.
trans-unit.target: All the same CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) work against sync table APIs, except now they will read from or write to a *local store*.

trans-unit.source: Before any sync table operations can be performed, the local store must be initialized.
trans-unit.target: Before any sync table operations can be performed, the local store must be initialized.

trans-unit.source: What is a local store?
trans-unit.target: What is a local store?

trans-unit.source: A local store is the data persistence layer on the client device.
trans-unit.target: A local store is the data persistence layer on the client device.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Mobile Apps client SDKs provide a default local store implementation.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Mobile Apps client SDKs provide a default local store implementation.

trans-unit.source: On Windows, Xamarin and Android, it is based on SQLite; on iOS, it is based on Core Data.
trans-unit.target: On Windows, Xamarin and Android, it is based on SQLite; on iOS, it is based on Core Data.

trans-unit.source: To use the SQLite-based implementation on Windows Phone or Windows Store 8.1, you need to install a SQLite extension.
trans-unit.target: To use the SQLite-based implementation on Windows Phone or Windows Store 8.1, you need to install a SQLite extension.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see [Windows 8.1: Enable offline sync].
trans-unit.target: For more details, see [Windows 8.1: Enable offline sync].

trans-unit.source: Android and iOS ship with a version of SQLite in the device operating system itself, so it is not necessary to reference your own version of SQLite.
trans-unit.target: Android and iOS ship with a version of SQLite in the device operating system itself, so it is not necessary to reference your own version of SQLite.

trans-unit.source: Developers can also implement their own local store.
trans-unit.target: Developers can also implement their own local store.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you wish to store data in an encrypted format on the mobile client, you can define a local store that uses SQLCipher for encryption.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you wish to store data in an encrypted format on the mobile client, you can define a local store that uses SQLCipher for encryption.

trans-unit.source: What is a sync context?
trans-unit.target: What is a sync context?

trans-unit.source: A *sync context* is associated with a mobile client object (such as `IMobileServiceClient` or `MSClient`) and tracks changes that are made with sync tables.
trans-unit.target: A *sync context* is associated with a mobile client object (such as `IMobileServiceClient` or `MSClient`) and tracks changes that are made with sync tables.

trans-unit.source: The sync context maintains an *operation queue* which keeps an ordered list of CUD operations (Create, Update, Delete) that will later be sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: The sync context maintains an *operation queue* which keeps an ordered list of CUD operations (Create, Update, Delete) that will later be sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: A local store is associated with the sync context using an initialize method such as `IMobileServicesSyncContext.InitializeAsync(localstore)` in the .NET client SDK.
trans-unit.target: A local store is associated with the sync context using an initialize method such as `IMobileServicesSyncContext.InitializeAsync(localstore)` in the .NET client SDK.

trans-unit.source: How offline synchronization works
trans-unit.target: How offline synchronization works

trans-unit.source: When using sync tables, your client code controls when local changes will be synchronized with an Azure Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: When using sync tables, your client code controls when local changes will be synchronized with an Azure Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: Nothing is sent to the backend until there is a call to *push* local changes.
trans-unit.target: Nothing is sent to the backend until there is a call to *push* local changes.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the local store is populated with new data only when there is a call to *pull* data.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the local store is populated with new data only when there is a call to *pull* data.

trans-unit.source: **Push**: Push is an operation on the sync context and sends all CUD changes since the last push.
trans-unit.target: **Push**: Push is an operation on the sync context and sends all CUD changes since the last push.

trans-unit.source: Note that it is not possible to send only an individual table's changes, because otherwise operations could be sent out of order.
trans-unit.target: Note that it is not possible to send only an individual table's changes, because otherwise operations could be sent out of order.

trans-unit.source: Push executes a series of REST calls to your Azure Mobile App backend, which in turn will modify your server database.
trans-unit.target: Push executes a series of REST calls to your Azure Mobile App backend, which in turn will modify your server database.

trans-unit.source: **Pull**: Pull is performed on a per-table basis and can be customized with a query to retrieve only a subset of the server data.
trans-unit.target: **Pull**: Pull is performed on a per-table basis and can be customized with a query to retrieve only a subset of the server data.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Mobile client SDKs then insert the resulting data into the local store.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Mobile client SDKs then insert the resulting data into the local store.

trans-unit.source: **Implicit Pushes**: If a pull is executed against a table that has pending local updates, the pull will first execute a push on the sync context.
trans-unit.target: **Implicit Pushes**: If a pull is executed against a table that has pending local updates, the pull will first execute a push on the sync context.

trans-unit.source: This helps minimize conflicts between changes that are already queued and new data from the server.
trans-unit.target: This helps minimize conflicts between changes that are already queued and new data from the server.

trans-unit.source: **Incremental Sync**: the first parameter to the pull operation is a *query name* that is used only on the client.
trans-unit.target: **Incremental Sync**: the first parameter to the pull operation is a *query name* that is used only on the client.

trans-unit.source: If you use a non-null query name, the Azure Mobile SDK will perform an *incremental sync*.
trans-unit.target: If you use a non-null query name, the Azure Mobile SDK will perform an *incremental sync*.

trans-unit.source: Each time a pull operation returns a set of results, the latest `__updatedAt` timestamp from that result set is stored in the SDK local system tables.
trans-unit.target: Each time a pull operation returns a set of results, the latest `__updatedAt` timestamp from that result set is stored in the SDK local system tables.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent pull operations will only retrieve records after that timestamp.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent pull operations will only retrieve records after that timestamp.

trans-unit.source: To use incremental sync, your server must return meaningful `__updatedAt` values and must also support sorting by this field.
trans-unit.target: To use incremental sync, your server must return meaningful `__updatedAt` values and must also support sorting by this field.

trans-unit.source: However, since the SDK adds its own sort on the updatedAt field, you cannot use a pull query that has its own `$orderBy$` clause.
trans-unit.target: However, since the SDK adds its own sort on the updatedAt field, you cannot use a pull query that has its own `$orderBy$` clause.

trans-unit.source: The query name can be any string you choose, but it must be unique for each logical query in your app.
trans-unit.target: The query name can be any string you choose, but it must be unique for each logical query in your app.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, different pull operations could overwrite the same incremental sync timestamp and your queries can return incorrect results.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, different pull operations could overwrite the same incremental sync timestamp and your queries can return incorrect results.

trans-unit.source: If the query has a parameter, one way to create a unique query name is to incorporate the parameter value.
trans-unit.target: If the query has a parameter, one way to create a unique query name is to incorporate the parameter value.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you are filtering on userid, your query name could be as follows:
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you are filtering on userid, your query name could be as follows:

trans-unit.source: If you want to opt out of incremental sync, pass `null` as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: If you want to opt out of incremental sync, pass `null` as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: In this case, all records will be retrieved on every call to `PullAsync`, which is potentially inefficient.
trans-unit.target: In this case, all records will be retrieved on every call to `PullAsync`, which is potentially inefficient.

trans-unit.source: **Purging**: You can clear the contents of the local store using `IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync`.
trans-unit.target: **Purging**: You can clear the contents of the local store using `IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync`.

trans-unit.source: This may be necessary if you have stale data in the client database, or if you wish to discard all pending changes.
trans-unit.target: This may be necessary if you have stale data in the client database, or if you wish to discard all pending changes.

trans-unit.source: A purge will clear a table from the local store.
trans-unit.target: A purge will clear a table from the local store.

trans-unit.source: If there are operations pending synchronization with the server database, the purge will throw an exception unless the *force purge* parameter is set.
trans-unit.target: If there are operations pending synchronization with the server database, the purge will throw an exception unless the *force purge* parameter is set.

trans-unit.source: As an example of stale data on the client, suppose in the "todo list" example, Device1 only pulls items that are not completed.
trans-unit.target: As an example of stale data on the client, suppose in the "todo list" example, Device1 only pulls items that are not completed.

trans-unit.source: Then, a todoitem "Buy milk" is marked completed on the server by another device.
trans-unit.target: Then, a todoitem "Buy milk" is marked completed on the server by another device.

trans-unit.source: However, Device1 will still have the "Buy milk" todoitem in local store because it is only pulling items that are not marked complete.
trans-unit.target: However, Device1 will still have the "Buy milk" todoitem in local store because it is only pulling items that are not marked complete.

trans-unit.source: A purge will clear this stale item.
trans-unit.target: A purge will clear this stale item.
